org.jtrim2.collections

Interface ReservablePollingQueue<T>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - the type of the elements allowed in the queue

    public interface ReservablePollingQueue<T>
    Defines a simple queue from which you can poll elements, but still keep reserving space in a limited capacity implementation after the element was polled.

    Note: Implementations of this queue may not support null elements.

    See ReservablePollingQueues for some default implementations.

    Thread safety

    Implementations of this interface are not required to be thread-safe and it is implementation dependent, if they are allowed to be called from multiple threads concurrently.

    Synchronization transparency

    The methods of this interface are required to be synchronization transparent, so they can be called in any context (e.g.: while holding a lock).
    See Also:
    ReservablePollingQueues

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods Default Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      default void clear()
      Removes all the elements from this queue.
      boolean isEmpty()
      Checks if this queue contains any element or not.
      boolean isEmptyAndNoReserved()
      Checks if this queue contains any element or not, and that there is no element reservation left.
      boolean offer(T entry)
      Adds the given element to the queue unless this queue as at its maximum capacity.
      default T poll()
      Removes one element from this queue, if there is one.
      ReservedElementRef<T> pollButKeepReserved()
      Removes one element from this queue, if there is one, but if this queue has limited capacity, don't keep reserving space preventing adding new element.

    • Method Detail

      • isEmpty

        boolean isEmpty()
        Checks if this queue contains any element or not. If this method return true, then poll and pollButKeepReserved will return null unless this queue gets new element added (normally by calling offer).

        Note that an empty queue does not mean that you will be able to add elements to it, even if this queue has a capacity more than zero, because space reservation not released are not counted for the purpose of isEmpty.

        Returns:
        true if this queue has some elements to be polled, false otherwise

      • isEmptyAndNoReserved

        boolean isEmptyAndNoReserved()
        Checks if this queue contains any element or not, and that there is no element reservation left. If this method return true, then poll and pollButKeepReserved will return null unless this queue gets new element added (normally by calling offer).

        If this method returns true and the queue has no implementation specific extra restrictions, then adding an element will succeed.

        Returns:
        true if this queue has some elements to be polled, false otherwise

      • offer

        boolean offer(T entry)
        Adds the given element to the queue unless this queue as at its maximum capacity. If the queue is currently at full capacity, then this method will do nothing, but return false.
        Parameters:
        entry - the new element to be added to the queue. This argument cannot be null.
        Returns:
        true if the given element was added to the queue, false if the queue was full and the queue remains unchanged

      • pollButKeepReserved

        ReservedElementRef<T> pollButKeepReserved()
        Removes one element from this queue, if there is one, but if this queue has limited capacity, don't keep reserving space preventing adding new element. This space reservation can be released by calling the release on the returned reference. That is, until you call release, the offset method will behave as if you did not yet remove this element.
        Returns:
        the reference to the polled element or null if this queue is currently empty

      • poll

        default T poll()
        Removes one element from this queue, if there is one. This method is effectively equivalent to calling pollButKeepReserved and immediately release the reference.
        Returns:
        the element polled from this queue or null if this queue is currently empty

      • clear

        default void clear()
        Removes all the elements from this queue. Subsequent poll call will return null unless a new element was added through offer. Note however that there might be some unreleased polled references, so you might not be able to add new elements after calling this method.

        The default implementation just calls poll until it returns null.
